glossary.content.anonymouselectionpermit: An anonymous election permit is the authorisation to vote. An anonymous election permit cannot be associated with a specific person and thus ensures the secrecy of the vote when it is cast. The anonymous election permit is cryptographically generated from the personalised election permit and the voting key. The seal of the electoral authority is not lost in the process. This is important in order to be able to check the validity of the election permit. The anonymous election permit can only be generated using the voting key that was sent to the electoral authority in a concealed form when applying for the election permit. Therefore, only one anonymous election permit can be calculated from the personalised election permit.
glossary.content.ballotpaper.text: A ballot paper is the form containing the referendum question and the response options.
glossary.content.ballotpaper.title: Ballot paper
glossary.content.election.text: A referendum is an election where voters choose between several possible answers to a specific referendum question. Election is the generic term that includes both the referendum and an election. That is why we usually speak of election here. In the case of a referendum we can also speak of a choice of topics, as opposed to a choice of persons. In the context of ABSTIMMUNG21 we speak of an online referendum similar to an online petition.
glossary.content.election.title: Referendum vs. Election
glossary.content.electionnotification.te: An election notification is the information about an election taking place. It states the time and topic of the election.
glossary.content.electionpapers.text: Ordering election documents or the online election application is similar to registering for postal voting with the electoral authority.
glossary.content.electionpapers.title: Ordering election papers
glossary.content.electionresultverificat: Anyone can verify the result of an election to check whether the published result matches the recorded valid votes.
glossary.content.electoralauthority.text: The electoral authority administrates the election process and determines who may participate in a vote.
glossary.content.encryptedvote.text: An encrypted vote is a vote that can only be decrypted after the election has finished. It can then be read. A voter encrypts their vote themselves. Only encrypted votes are stored in the blockchain. Only the electoral authority can decrypt an encrypted vote.
glossary.content.encryptedvote.title: Encrypted vote
Personalised election permits are issued by the electoral authority and are a prerequisite for taking part in a vote. The electoral authority ensures that the person applying to vote is authorised to vote and that only one election permit is issued for each person authorised to vote. The personalised election permit can be assigned to the voter because the person and the election permit are known to the electoral authority. The personalised election permit cannot be used to vote because otherwise the secrecy of the ballot would be broken. Only the anonymous election permit can be used to vote.
glossary.content.voter.text: A voter is the participant of an election/referendum on the Internet.
glossary.content.voter.title: Voter
glossary.content.votingkey.text: The election key is a part of the election application that only the voter knows. It is encrypted and sent to the electoral administration. There, the encrypted secret is given a seal and returned to the voter as a personalized ballot paper.
glossary.content.votingkey.title: Voting key
glossary.headline.title: glossary
faq.headline.title: FAQ
faq.content.getstarted.text:
First of all: We can hardly wait either! On openpetition.de/opn-vote you can always see the latest information about the election.

The next phase will start in mid-August: We will invite all people with a verified openPetition account by e-mail to have a voting key and election permit created easily by our system.
From September to October, you can vote online in the first nationwide online referendum using your own ballot paper!
The results will be announced on 31.10.2025.
faq.content.getstarted.title: When does it start or when will I receive more information about the online election?
faq.content.process.text:
It's all a question of security: thanks to state-of-the-art technical solutions, we can only guarantee that the principles of democratic elections are always fulfilled if the time intervals between the individual steps are observed: universal, direct, free, equal, secret.

Time is paying particular attention to the last principle "secret": The secret lies in the fact that every person can exercise their right to vote in such a way that it is impossible to trace how they voted.
faq.content.process.title: Why is the online voting process so fragmented and time-consuming?
faq.content.participation.text: Even though we are guided by the electoral law for the German Bundestag, we would also like to enable people without German citizenship (but who live in Germany) to participate. People with German citizenship must verify their account on openPetition in advance with ePerso or by postal PIN. People without German citizenship must also verify their account beforehand and can only do this by using their Post-PIN by post.
faq.content.participation.title: Who can take part in this year's referendum?
faq.content.offlinepossible.text: We are offering online voting for the first time this year and we are delighted that so many people are taking part. However, we do not want to exclude anyone, which is why you can also take part in the vote by letter this year. It was possible to order the voting documents until August 10 via www.openpetition.de/abstimmung21 . After that, you can only register for the vote online. In this way, we can ensure that no one takes part in the referendum twice.
faq.content.offlinepossible.title: I do not want to vote online. Can I also take part in the election by letter?
faq.content.whywebuildit.text: Software for democratic co-determination such as elections or referendums should not only come from large tech companies or be in the hands of the state. The democratic tools of the future belong in the hands of citizens.
faq.content.whywebuildit.title: Why is openPetition building secure online voting software?
faq.content.topics.text:
The following issues will be voted on this year: Wealth tax for the super-rich, arms deliveries to Ukraine, debt brake, climate protection law.

From May to mid-June, topics could be voted on by signing petitions. The two topics with the most signatures made it onto the election list:
www.openpetition.de/abstimmung21

In addition, two topics were added to the election list - also through a voting procedure - via our cooperation partner ABSTIMMUNG21 e.V.
faq.content.topics.title: How did the topics for this year's election come about?
faq.content.populists.text:
The opposite is true: with fair rules, direct democracy can take the wind out of populists' sails. Because it makes politics more transparent and gives all citizens more influence - not just those who shout the loudest.
With independent fact checks, a debate format and a neutral comparison of positions, we ensure that everyone is informed objectively. Due to the length of the process - up to four years at federal level - referendums are less suitable for populist quick fixes. Instead, they trigger intensive debates throughout society. This breaks up bubbles, broadens and deepens the discussion - and thus contributes to objectification.
In general, referendums are a mirror of society, but are not responsible for its state. Society can recognize how it is doing. It does not always have to come to a referendum. The preliminary effect of direct democracy ensures that politicians have to deal with the diverse interests of the population. Direct democracy also has an outlet function. It can relieve people of the widespread feeling that they are not being heard. By enabling everyone to play an active role in shaping the future, direct democracy points the finger less at "those at the top". With good opportunities to launch a popular initiative, it is up to each and every one of us to decide for ourselves how we feel.
faq.content.populists.title: Are referendums playing into the hands of populists?
faq.content.legitimation.text:
Together with our cooperation partner ABSTIMMUNG21, we rely on Article 20 paragraph 2 of the Basic Law. It states: "All state authority emanates from the people. It shall be exercised by the people in elections and referendums [...]."

There is therefore already a certain legitimacy for the nationwide vote. A concrete implementation law that would guarantee binding force does not yet exist. That is why we are organizing the vote ourselves.

Nevertheless, the election can and should not only be a signal for the instrument of the referendum, but also have an impact on specific issues. Together with ABSTIMMUNG21, we are therefore trying to grow and encourage more and more people to take part in this experiment in democracy.

Everything we do is funded by donations. If many people not only vote in the Bundestag, but also vote on an issue on openPetition & ABSTIMMUNG21, then parliament is given a clear mandate to act.
faq.content.legitimation.title: Are the results of the election in Germany legally binding?
faq.content.swiss.text:
Direct democracy in Switzerland may be a model in principle, but it is not so in decisive points and above all not transferable to Germany 1:1 . In contrast to Switzerland, we favor a three-stage model of direct democracy at state and federal level: popular initiative, petition for a referendum, referendum. After the initiative, the possibility of a judicial review is provided for (preventive review of norms). The Federal Constitutional Court can thus examine the compatibility of a draft law with the Basic Law and international law and not allow the initiative if fundamental and minority rights would be attacked. The petition for a referendum and the referendum then no longer take place. This is a significant difference to direct democracy in Switzerland.

There, there is no provision for a comprehensive preliminary review. Switzerland also does not have its own constitutional court. Laws passed by the population can only be brought before the European Court of Human Rights afterwards, which then examines whether they comply with the Convention on Human Rights.
faq.content.swiss.title: Is Switzerland a role model for us?
faq.content.extremelawchange.text: No. We are guided by the three-stage referendum legislation in the German federal states and the joint legislative proposal of the democracy organizations Mehr Demokratie, OMNIBUS für Direkte Demokratie and Democracy International. This provides that fundamental and minority rights are protected. This is ensured by the fact that every draft law drawn up by a popular initiative is examined by the Federal Constitutional Court at the request of the government or parliament for its compatibility with the Basic Law and international law - and can be stopped in the event of a violation. This "preventive review of norms" already exists in direct democratic procedures in all federal states.
faq.content.extremelawchange.title: Are extreme legislative changes such as the "introduction of the death penalty" possible?
faq.content.brexit.text: Brexit is not a suitable example of direct democracy in Germany. It was initiated by the British government and abused by the parties for populist purposes. There was no clear voting template and no balanced information for the survey. Furthermore, in Switzerland, for example, it is common practice for international treaties to be voted on twice: once at the beginning of the negotiations and once at the end, when all the details of the agreement are on the table.
faq.content.brexit.title: Hasn't BREXIT shown that referendums are dangerous?
faq.content.whydowedoit.text:
Our society is - today and always - facing various major challenges. These can best be solved together in dialog with the population. That's why openPetition primarily promotes petitions. The instruments of direct democracy provide civil society with another opportunity to put ideas and concepts to the vote. It is unlikely that people feel 100% picked up by a party - but at federal level, elections are the only form where citizens are asked directly. Why is the population only trusted to be the sovereign every 4 years? Referendums help to safeguard political decisions and reveal where there is room for improvement. In this way, confidence in one's own self-efficacy and in democracy can be strengthened and helps to combat political disenchantment.

The legal introduction of nationwide referendums has been blocked for years. Yet there is a need for this and representative surveys regularly show that more than two thirds of the population are in favor of it. By putting specific, important issues to the vote, we are making the nationwide referendum tangible and tangible. We show: More democracy is also possible at federal level!
faq.content.whydowedoit.title: So far, openPetition has mainly dealt with petitions. Why referendums now?
faq.content.security.text:
Democratic elections and votes must be able to guarantee a secret and equal vote - even if they take place online.

opn.vote guarantees the secrecy of the ballot through an anonymous digital ballot paper. Only the voter knows the digital ballot paper and no one else. This is made possible by the voting key, which is only generated on the voter's own device and is only known to the voter. The ballot paper is cryptographically signed so that it cannot be forged or duplicated.

The votes cast are stored publicly and immutably in a decentralized blockchain, the Gnosis Chain. As the votes cannot be assigned to individuals, voting secrecy is maintained. Anyone can check their own vote and, after the election, check all votes for validity and count them themselves. No central authority can intervene in the casting of votes and falsify the result.

You can find more information on the voting procedure on our opn.vote blog in English.
faq.content.security.title: How do we ensure that online voting is secure? (Voting secrecy secured and manipulation excluded)

pdf.register.entitles: The election permit entitles you to participate in:
pdf.register.lawhint: Voting must be done in person and without interference. Any attempt to manipulate the election, transferring, buying, or selling ballot papers is prohibited and will be prosecuted under Sections 107 and 108b of the German Criminal Code.
pdf.register.registerexplained.1: Voting registration (creation of voting key and ballot paper) and the voting period are separated to ensure a secret ballot. No temporal or spatial (IP address) connection can be established between registration and voting.
pdf.register.registerexplained.2: The ballot paper is active during the election period and must be uploaded or scanned to cast your vote. Use the election link to cast your vote.
pdf.votingkey.additionalinfo.electionove: Here is an overview of current elections and votes on openPetition:
pdf.votingkey.additionalinfo.votingkeyex: With the voting key, you can have a ballot paper issued for current and future elections. Only the ballot paper entitles you to participate in an election.
If you have lost your ballot paper, you can use this voting key to have a new one issued.
